docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN a child lies suffering from illness, injury or grief, in a hospital, homeless shelter, refugee camp or even in the stillborn silence of a tiny coffin -- Hillary Roberts has them covered. Under her direction, volunteers make 15,000 blankets a year and send them to those in need of comfort. She started five years ago and now works with 3,700 New Jerseyans who, like her, want to help others.
docs.abstract: Article on Project Linus New Jersey Inc, founded by Hillary Roberts, whose 3,700 volunteers statewide make 15,000 blankets a year and send them to sick, injured, grieving, homeless or refugee children in US and abroad; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: CITRIN--Hillary. Hillary, it has been several years since last I wrote and I would like to let you know what has gone on in our family since then. Your nephew Ethan still has a heart of gold but now it is in the body of a young man. He is handsome and smart and beautiful as you were. Your nephew Hunter is a great athlete and has your sense of humor. You and he would have had a great time together. Luanne is still keeping me together after all these years. And Dad continues to be the strength that he was when you were with us. Luckily for us, his wife, Roz, keeps him well. It has been 23 years and it feels like it was yesterday when I saw you last. All my love, Marc

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton fielded a few tough questions yesterday from some of the children she has said she will speak for if her husband is elected President. After delivering a speech on education reform at the Bank Street College, Mrs. Clinton visited an eighth-grade government class in the adjoining Bank Street School for Children, where students asked whether the family-leave bill supported by her husband, Gov. Bill Clinton, would hurt businesses, whether children should be allowed to divorce their parents and what she would do to improve public education. In detailed responses, Mrs. Clinton did not talk down to her audience.

headline.main: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Hillary Clinton; Talking Up To Children On Politics

docs.lead_paragraph: "FOR more than five years I had dreamed of a new adventure." There hardly could be a more enticing opening line, especially when its author is Sir Edmund Hillary, conqueror of Mount Everest, and it begins the account of his latest expedition to the Himalayas. Surely what follows will be an epic tale of courageous men challenging the wilderness and themselves.

docs.lead_paragraph: LIVING to tell the tale is one thing; but telling the tale is another. A further consideration is the manner in which the tale is told. On all three the young British fighter pilot who wrote this book qualifies handsomely, and adds luster to the literature of World War II.
